comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Lovely old picture, thank you.  Is the Turbinia still on show in two pieces?

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: No Turbinia was restored to her former glory, after a fund was launched - jointly sponsored by the North East Coast Institution of Engineers and Shipbuilders and Newcastle Corporation. Thanks to the corporations above and other Institutions and subscribers, Turbinia was restored (as nearly as possible) to her original condition and housed in an annexe at the Science and Engineering Museum in Newcastle. This was officially opened by Admiral Sir Casper John, First Sea Lord and Chief of Naval Staff, on September 15th, 1961. Turbinia was then moved in 1994 to her new home, Discovery Museum, where people lined the streets to watch the journey through the City of Newcastle. There's a video on Youtube showing the move, I believe this is the link below. www.youtube.com/watch?v=AefE-sXygyU

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
Thank you TWAM, it's lovely to see information like this about my old part of England.
I come from Chester-le-Street but have lived for the last nearly forty years here in New Zealand.
I'm very glad that this site and TWAM have met.

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: FrigateRN - Didn't realise you were from Chester-le-street, after you said the site was run from New Zealand. Glad we can share the history of the area with you and am glad you are enjoying it.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
Yep TWAM, from old Castra-la-Strata but swallowed the anchor here in the Land of the Long White Cloud.
I'm very glad I found your site and you can rest assured that your pictures and commentaries are much appreciated here, thank you.
